subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: A couple of questions from a newbie
msgSnippet: ... None of the points I made in my long posting have anything to do with English T.O.: they reflect the worldwide experience with orthographies of all sorts,
messageBody:
Paige Gabhart scripsit:

> Thank you, Moira, for pointing out what Mr. Read actually intended
> for QS. I have been arguing against this idea that QS needs to be
> standardized ever since I started this group. People keep writing
> that we must have standardized spelling. I guess this is a hangover
> from what they've been taught all their lives with Trad. Orth.

None of the points I made in my long posting have anything to do with
English T.O.: they reflect the worldwide experience with orthographies
of all sorts, from French to Czech to Akkadian to Chinese. In a context
of mass literacy and mass publication, or even just elite literacy,
standardized orthographies have beaten non-standardized ones every single
time, and there is no reason to expect that to change.

> People don't seem to realize that a rigid standardization of spelling
> in QS just sets us back on the road that got TO in such a mess to
> begin with.

In the long run, yes. English orthography was standardized three
centuries ago (except for trivial adjustments in North American
varieties, most of which have nothing to do with North American accents
particularly), on the basis of a pronunciation in use two to three
centuries before *that*. Most alphabetic systems get improved every
century or so to take sound-changes into account, but English has missed
its last five or six appointments with destiny. :-)

What is more, it took ten years to adjust German orthography the last
time, where only four countries were involved, and there is still
stiff resistance. At least fifty countries make English an official
language or use it heavily as a native language, so getting past all
the bureaucracies would probably take a hundred years by itself, and
the reform would be obsolete before it was fully adopted.

We have to begin with the facts on the ground, which are that QS is
not a phonetic alphabet in the sense of IPA, that it can't express
all the distinctions needed by every accent (to say nothing of all the
distinctions in all the accents simultaneously), and that no one accent
is standard worldwide. And then we have to ask what serves the greatest
good of the greatest number.

--
